thread.section_title: Business Breaking News | Finance & Business News | News.com.au
thread.title: CBA retail offer falls short by half, will launch bookbuild
thread.title_full: CBA retail offer falls short by half, will launch bookbuild

author: Michael Roddan
title: CBA retail offer falls short by half, will launch bookbuild
text:
THE Commonwealth Bank has raised $1.5 billion from household investors for its capital raising program â€” half the amount it wanted.
The bank announced it had raised the cash from the proposed $2.9 billion it wanted from retail investors for its $5.1 billion capital raising as the lender seeks to strength its position ahead of new capital requirements.
The bank will launch a retail bookbuild to complete the capital raising, which is fully underwritten.
Retail shareholders were offered the opportunity to buy new CBA shares at $71.50.
CBA's retail offer brings the total amount raised by CBA so far to $3.6 billion, when combined with the institutional component.
The bank is aiming to raise $5.1 billion, following other major lenders in tapping shareholders to bolster capital positions to meet new regulatory requirements by mid 2016.
The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority's new rules will require the lenders to bolster their capital reserve risk ratios from 16 to 25 per cent.
Around 50 per cent of retail shareholders, by value, took up the retail offer.
CBA said it would be launching a retail bookbuild to fill the shortfall, after around 21 million entitlement were not taken up, which will be open to shareholders who did not participate in the retail offer.
The bank said it was bringing the bookbuild forward by a day amid sharp volatility in the equity markets.
Originally published as CBA retail offer falls short by half
